{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3495203,"name":"","username":"TheANT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theant/{size}/197187_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T23:31:59.372Z","cooked":"

I am currently working on field localization. I have been following this amazing comment on another thread. I have been setting up the Meta Tag 2 with the limelight. I wanted to know:

  1. If I am doing this correctly (or if there is a more efficent way)
  2. How to use this feature on multiple limelights to get a more accurate position. (possibly by averaging all the limelight Pose2d values)

Our code is here. Please use the TeleopMove branch because the main branch is outdated right now.

All help is appricated.

Please note I am not well-versed with WPILib’s Odometry/Pose Estimators and command-based robots

It seems like you guys are using Odometry and a PoseEstimator. According to the docs here and here, it’s suggested you just use a SwerveDrivePoseEstimator (or one of the others if you aren’t using swerve), which should have the functionality of both Odometry and PoseEstimator.

In terms of fusing the data for multiple Limelights, you can simply call addVisionUpdate() for every result you have with a different standard deviation. Since I’m not familiar with command-based, hopefully someone else knows the best way to actually get that data from the limelights. For my team, which doesn’t use the command based framework, I created a custom Camera class, which could handle both Limelight and PhotonVision. You could just make a Limelight class, and have a list of Limelights in your TrackingSubsystem, and you’d loop over each to set the orientation, get the pose, and add it to the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator.

Hopefully that somewhat answered your questions, but if you have more feel free to ask.

hat data from

Our team does know how to get the value from the limelights and how to use it in command based programming. (At least well enough. Probally not the most effecient.) Your responce awnsered all our questions.

Thank you
